content.description: Start on top of the blocks just right of center. Head up the crack for a few bolts. Exit the crack left by making delicate slab moves on that “highly featured rock” that was mentioned. Head up a delightfully juggy feature. Trend up and left before heading back right to the anchors.
content.location: Just right of center. Start on top of the large blocks.

content.description: Did you know lichen is actually two very different organisms working together in order to make their lifestyle work. The same could be said of the two people who came together to make this route happen. Two very different organisms came together to make yet another enjoyable low angle face climb on this beautiful slab of rock. Start at the lowest point of the wall. Climb up clipping bolts one and two before stepping left into the cracked groove. The next few bolts can be climbs a couple of ways, straight up walking feet in the crack clipping bolts low to your right or with a hand on the crack, feet on the slab with bolts above you until a mantle opportunity presents itself. Then continue on a more obvious path to the anchor.
content.location: The second route from the left.

content.description: More fun in the Garden. To get started walk up hill a few steps from the base of the Trellis Tree (that's the wild crooked one on the right side of the base of the cliff) which is a good place to belay for this route. A steep but not so difficult start gets you on to more typical FG slab climbing. Pick your way through pretty chill terrain until you get to the final bulge. There are a couple of ways to surmount the steepest section but I really like traversing up and right with feet in the angling slab-crack until it is possible to get a foot onto the upper slab and mantle. Things are thinner up here but if you look around you will find a comfortable solution. There is a nice side-pull to the right from which you can clip the anchors.
content.location: This is the far right bolt line on the wall currently. If you are standing at the base of the "trellis tree" (you'll know it when you see it) look straight up and you will see the bolt line heading up and slightly to the right.

content.description: This was the first line at the cliff that was cleaned and bolted. Start up the crack next to the blocks,  then follow the featured slab up to a nifty hole in the center of the cliff. Exit up and left before snaking back. Make several moves along the crack before heading to the anchors!
content.location: The middle route on the slab. Start just to the left of the blocks.

content.description: This is an absolutely delightful climb. One of my favorite sport climbs of the grade that I have done. The first bolt is high but getting there is quite comfortable. Staying left of the bolts climb super featured rock until it blanks out a little demanding a little more attention. move up to the arete and a good stance before climbing to the anchor. Highly recommended for new leaders and people who like good rock climbs.Pronounced roughly: Bloomin'-maid-chin (Flower Girl in German)
content.location: This is the far left bolt line. Climbs up a highly featured groove and eventually to the arete.

content.description: This wall consists primarily of moderate, low angle climbing on highly featured rock. Expect engaging sequences with ample protection on modern glue-in bolts.
